> [{quoted}](name=GigglesO,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=EYWd1mno,comment-id=00040004,timestamp=2018-11-04T21:56:24.649+0000)
>
> Maybe we could get some context on this, is there a reason other than possibly to keep players from gaining too much exp from a game?

Sure.

When developing the new leveling system last year, we were left with a tough decision. For 99.9% of players, it was impossible to level more than once in a game (even in a 60+ minute game running BOTH boosts and with bonus mission XP). But in the absolute WORST case (Level 1, same conditions) it was actually possible to level up 7 times (Level 1 to 8). The amount of development time to get the end of game ceremony to support 7 levels ups wasn't worth just how not-very-often it happens. So in the case where you would level up twice, we lower you to 1 XP short of the next level.

It's a not ideal trade off, but part of game development is making hard decisions like this. For how unlikely this is to happen looking at the numbers, I think we made the right call and I'd make it again. It impacts low level smurfs, and the impact is quite minor (a game worth of XP at most).
If people aren't getting what they pay for, you should probably lower the price based on summoner level.  Otherwise, you're just ripping those people off.

Couldn't you just make XP bank? If XP overflows over desired value (such like player would level-up multiple times), store it into XP bank, then next like 10 games each will provide 10% of the bank. So it doesn't give Yp bursts while simultaneously no XP is lost. Which is especially imortant If someone buys the XP boost.

Or, even this:

XP gained that game reduced to 1 XP below the second level gain, extra XP added to bank. Every game after that where XP gain is less than 2 levels would take from the bank to increase to 1 XP less than the second level gain. Games that were *more* than 2 levels would follow the same thing - reduce to 1 below second level and add to the bank.

Then you're potentially running into things where you can just bank EXP and never run out of it, making it impossible to use it all. And that would make people mad anyway since they would look at it as if Riot put that EXP in a trust fund and you can't take it out when you need it. And then you can still run into the same problem of getting close to leveling the second time and that a part of that 10% stored EXP (plus your got EXP), getting stored again in the bank.

In any case, the situation is still the same no matter the implementation.

This exemplifies where League has been heading for the last few years pretty well. You recognize a problem, but rather than put in the time and effort to correct that problem or apply an appropriate method to handle it, you instead opt for the easier and short-sighted response of just cutting it off at the knees. Then, you tell anyone that has an issue with it that it was a "hard decision, but deal with it." This isn't an unintended casualty due to an unforeseen issue with how the system was set up. This was a deliberate choice to frustrate the customer experience, break expectations, and lower the value of purchased services for the sake of making things easier for the design/coding teams.

Of course, then you contradict this mentality with your precious Mission and Mastery systems giving me 10 popup notifications after every game that I have to individually address before I can queue again. So it seems you're only willing to put in the effort for the systems you care about.

Another poster suggested a simple "experience bank" that would keep track of overflow experience, but I would have gone a step further. Since you were already reworking the system and discovered this issue, you could have set things up in such a way that the game keeps track of an account's level while the player themselves could "redeem" their experience in their own time to claim level-up rewards. This lets players decide when they want to deal with the system while still allowing the account to reflect its level virtually, ensuring they're matched in-game appropriately.

But I guess that's asking too much, isn't it.

You don't have to buy a single boost in order to reach level 30.
Riot considerably lowered the leveling curve (by half what it was usually required years ago) but they also put in safeguards to prevent smurfs from grinding out levels in a matter of few hours/a day. This makes sure that both parties (people who casually play a few games a day and smurfs), don't have two massively different experiences in terms of account EXP progress.

You're still going to get more experience if you play more games than the average player but the difference isn't going to be miles apart. It's not about keeping you playing for longer because if you already  want to level to 30, it is assumed you want Ranked or to keep playing for longer. So no, Riot's not forcing you to sit at your computer for hours on end in order to "fully" experience League.

And remember, Runes are no longer account level restricted.
You can use a full page from level 1.

What lies are you talking about? Available from level one? You mean the _**presets**_? The presets that nobody except the assassins and ADCs like because the options are limited and tend to be inneffective?

You actually unlock being able to make full pages at level 15, wtf are you trying to lie about here?

>You actually unlock being able to make full pages at level 15, wtf are you trying to lie about here?

No, you don't.
The whole point about the new rune system was to remove the level 30 account lockout for full rune pages, earning 1 slot per level. I'm not talking about the presets. Presets allow you to actually play the game with a full rune page that, in all situations for the vast majority of champions, cover the most basic options for a wide variety of classes.

Even if you're playing your champion suboptimally, Runes are actually quite a significant power budget for champions so it stands to reason Riot is not allowing you to go into a game without a single rune page equipped. And for the level 15 part, this allows you to actually learn about your given selection of rune pages as a new player instead of immediately being burdened to sink time into understanding a system you don't know how it even interacts with any of the champions - speaking from a new player standpoint.

Which means, the entire reworked runes and your profile experience is geared towards new player experience instead of smurfs who would just want to power through the leveling and stomp players who don't even understand the game yet.
